content.html:
Clear, accurate, and concise text makes interfaces more usable and builds trust. Strive to write text that is understandable by anyone, anywhere, regardless of their culture or language.

In addition to these guidelines, be sure to consult guidelines for specific UI elements, such as Errors, Dialogs, Settings, and Data formats

Speak directly to users as “you,” not “me.” Don’t put words in the users’ mouths, with phrases that use “I” or “my.”

Exceptions include:

  • Some legal opt-ins: “I agree to follow the UX Writing Guidelines.”
  • Some Google Play categories, such as "My music" or "My books"
Rewrite to focus on the user and what they can do with your app, rather than what you or your app is doing for the user.

figures.src: Get started with these popular posts on Google+.
figures.caption: Do.

figures.src: To get you started, we’re showing you popular posts on Google+.
figures.caption: Don't.

content.html: One exception is when a human (not software) actually does take action for a user, such as reviewing an appeal or responding to a suggestion. Here, the use of “we” is appropriate and much more personable than the forced passive alternative.

figures.src: We’ll review your appeal and respond within a few days.
figures.caption: Do.

figures.src: Your appeal will be reviewed, and you will receive a response within a few days.
figures.caption: Don't.

content.html: UI text assists navigation and discovery. The best UI text is in small chunks that are not as much read as scanned.

figures.src: Send money to anyone in the US who has an email address. It’s fast, easy, and free.
figures.caption: Do.

figures.src: Send (and receive) money with friends and family in the US with an email address. It’s a two-step process with little-to-no latency and there aren’t any charges for the recipients of the money.
figures.caption: Don't.

content.html: Keep your sentences and phrases short, with as few concepts as possible.

figures.src: Read the instructions that came with your phone.
figures.caption: Do.

figures.src: Consult the documentation that came with your phone for further instructions.
figures.caption: Don't.

content.html: Use active verbs (“the dog bit the tree”) not passive verbs (“the tree was bitten”), except when the passive is shorter and simpler (“tree bitten”) or when there is no clear subject.

Most UI happens now, so you can write in the present.

When you need to write in the past or future, use simple verb forms.

modules.title: Try to write in the present

content.html: Uset’s easier for users to scan and understand simple, direct language as they skim through an interface.

figures.src: Would you like to save your changes?
figures.caption: Don't.

content.html: When choosing among synonyms, pick the simplest word.

modules.title: Use simple words that everyone knows

content.html: Avoid terms that only industry insiders know, and don't rely on the names invented for UI features.

figures.src: “Ok Google” isn’t supported on your phone
figures.caption: Do.

figures.src: “Ok Google” is only supported on dual-core devices
figures.caption: Don't.

content.html: Generic terms like "slider" and "menu" are fine, but direct users to the labels on UI elements, not the kind of element (such as menu or button).
You can skip many common introductory phrases and get right to the point.

figures.src: Are you sure you want to delete this photo?
figures.caption: Don't.

figures.src: You must register before you can vote
figures.caption: Don't.

content.html: The framing concept of an action is typically a verb. Pick one and use it consistently across the micro-narrative of an action.

modules.title: Use consistent verbs across the arc of an action

content.html: If a sentence includes an action for the user to take and instructions for achieving it, start the sentence with that action.

figures.src: To remove a photo from this album, drag it to the trash
figures.caption: Do.

figures.src: Drag a photo to the trash to remove it from this album
figures.caption: Don't.

modules.title: Lead with the goal, not the method

content.html: Don’t burden the user with every detail and caution up front. Reveal increasing detail about features as the user explores them and needs the information.

figures.src: Are you sure you want to remove this downloaded book? You won’t be able to access it unless you’re online.
figures.caption: Don't.

content.html: Avoid “never” and other absolutes.

modules.title: Text for buttons and related elements

content.html: Buttons appear in dialogs and as blue or underlined text.

figures.src:
Button

Usage

[ Action ]

See above guideline about using consistent verbs.

Back

Allows multi-step processes

Cancel

Cancels an action

Dismiss

Causes a message or dialog to disappear without any consequences

Done

Confirms the completion of a multi-step process

Got it

Causes a message or dialog to disappear without any consequences (similar to OK)

Learn more

Takes the user to additional content

Next

Takes the user to the next step of a multi-step process

No thanks

Allows a user to decline

Not now

Don’t use this abused phrase except in rare cases where the call to action in the dialog is essential to the functionality of the product, for legal reasons, or for another urgent reason. Never use “Not now” as a mechanism to avoid providing a “No thanks” option.

OK

Allows the user to confirm an action that’s relevant to the task at hand

Skip

Gives the user a way to avoid an interruption and proceed with a task

content.html: Text in your UI should complement your visual UI: intuitive, efficient, casual, and trustworthy. Charm peeks through, but never upstages the user.

figures.src:
MyApp isn’t responding

Do you want to close it?
figures.caption: Do.

figures.src:
Sorry!

Activity in MyAppActivity (in the  MyApp app) is not responding
figures.caption: Don't.

modules.title: Be friendly, respectful, and focus on the user

content.html: Don’t brag or over-promise. Reveal what a feature does, don’t say how great it is.
Focus on the benefits of each feature. Omit implementation details, caveats, and restrictions at the entry points to features (buttons, menu items, links, and promotions).

figures.src: To save power, switch Location mode to Battery saving mode.
figures.caption: Do.

figures.src: Manually control GPS to prevent other apps from using it.
figures.caption: Don't.

content.html: Present information in a positive light: it’s reassuring.

figures.src: Use 24 characters or fewer for file names.
figures.caption: Do.

figures.src: Your file name must be less than 25 characters.
figures.caption: Don't.

content.html:
For every message, ask yourself: does the user really need to know this? Err on the side of letting users stay focused on their own tasks. Sometimes the most effective UI is no text at all.

Avoid messages that suggest that it’s surprising or unusual that a user’s simple action was successful.

figures.src:
Signing in...

Your phone is contacting Google. This can take up to five minutes.
figures.caption: Do.

figures.src:
Signing in...

Your phone needs to communicate with Google servers to sign in to your account. This may take up to five minutes.
figures.caption: Don't.

content.html:
Use sentence-style caps for all titles, headings, labels, menu items – any place where you might be tempted to use “Title-Style Caps.”

Avoid ALL-CAPS except where the material spec requires them, for example, the Button style.
Don’t capitalize the things you create or work with when using that product.

modules.title: Capitalize product names only when referring to a product as a product

content.html:
For labels, hover text, setting labels, stacks of links, promos, and so on, avoid periods. This gives you the flexibility to mix sentences and sentence fragments, for example, in lists. It also reduces visual clutter and helps readers parse your text at a glance. Skip the colon after UI labels (“Share with” not “Share with:”).

Use a period or force fragments into full sentences where:  

  • You need to use more than one sentence – even if they’re short sentences.
  • You have a set of parallel labels where one of the set must be a sentence. Make them all full sentences and use periods (or question marks, etc.).
  • The sentence is part of a larger, more formal UI element, such as body text in a dialog.

modules.title: Skip periods and other unnecessary punctuation

content.html: Don't make a sentence harder to understand just to follow this rule. For example, "do not" can give more emphasis than "don't" when you really mean it.

figures.src: it’s, can’t, wouldn’t, you’re, you’ve, haven’t, don’t
figures.caption: Do.

figures.src: it is, cannot, would not, it’ll, should’ve
figures.caption: Don't.

content.html: Ask yourself, would someone shout (exclaim) that?

figures.src: Learn about the new features of Calendar!
figures.caption: Don't.

content.html:
Use numerals in place of words for numbers.

One exception is when mixing uses of numbers: "Enter two 3s."

Omit punctuation after phrases and labels to create a cleaner and more readable interface.

Use punctuation to add clarity or be grammatically correct.

figures.src:
Glyph/character

Description

Periods

.

Omit for fragments and single sentences in affordances like toasts, snackbars, butterbars, and labels. Do punctuate full sentences in body text, for example, in the body of dialogs.  

Place inside quotation marks (unless you’re telling the reader what to enter and it’s ambiguous whether to include the period).

Commas

,

Place inside of quotation marks.

Use the serial comma.

Exclamation points

!

Avoid exclamation points for anything you wouldn’t actually shout out loud (exclaim).

Colons

:

: or \u003A

Omit from labels, for example, in the labels for fields in a form.

Quotation marks

 

“ “ or \u201C

” ” or \u201D

‘ ‘ or \u2018

’ ’ or \u2019

Use real quotation marks, not the inch and foot symbols.

The right single quotation mark symbol is also used for apostrophes.

Never use the generic quotes ", ' or free-standing accents `, ´ (\u0022, \u0027, \u0060, \u00B4). These are never right for quotation marks, apostrophes, or primes.

Primes

′ or \u2032

and

″ or \u2033

Use prime (′) only in abbreviations for feet, arcminutes, and minutes. For example: 3° 15′

Use double-prime (″) only in abbreviations for inches, arcminutes, and minutes. For example: 3° 15′ 35″

Do not use generic quotes ", ' or free-standing accents `, ´ for primes.

Ellipses

 …

Option-;
…

Use to indicate an action in progress ("Downloading…") or incomplete or truncated text. No space before the ellipses.

Omit from menu items or buttons that open a dialog or start some other process.

Midline ellipses (three-bullet glyphs) are also used to represent numeric truncation and the redaction of sensitive data, such as credit cards.

Double angle brackets

 >>, << « or \u00AB

» or \u00BB

Omit from links or buttons that open another page or move to the next or previous step in a process.

Em dash

 

—

— or \u2014

Shift+Option -

Avoid using em dashes.

En dash

–

– or \u2013

Option+ -

Use an en dash instead of a hyphen to indicate a range, without spaces (in English).

Avoid using dashes to separate text. If you must use dashes for this purpose – like this – use an en dash surrounded by spaces.

Example of use with a range:
8:00 AM–12:30 PM
3–5 kg

Hyphen

-

Use hyphens to avoid ambiguity in compound adjective-noun or noun-participle pairs and in some prefixes.

For example:

anti-inflammatory
5-mile walk

Parentheses

(  )

Use parentheses only to define acronyms or jargon.

For example:
“Secure web connections are based on a technology called SSL (the secure sockets layer).”

content.html:
People of all ages, cultures, backgrounds, and education levels rely on the English versions of products. Many of the writing guidelines support writing for non-native English speakers and for localization (the translation and adaptation of content for international use). Simple, clear English makes it easy for anyone to understand your product.

This section focuses on how to write English in a way that makes products more useful in English and other languages around the world.
Culturally specific language can be difficult to translate and may be inappropriate in some locales.

modules.title: Don’t use culturally specific idioms, metaphors, or examples

figures.src: You really hit it out of the park!
figures.caption: Don't.

content.html: Interfaces for languages with right-to-left scripts may be mirrored when a product is localized.

English is one of the few languages that allows gender ambiguity (for example, “you can see their picture”). Most other languages must be more specific (“you can see his or her picture,” for example).

Be specific about gender whenever possible (his, her, and so on).

Provide clear descriptions of your strings as comments in the code. Linguists rely on context from descriptions to translate strings in a meaningful way to other cultures, beyond literal translations of English text.
